home.title: Life can take you in many directions. Career Skills helps you think ahead.

nav.copy-results-to-link: Copy the link to the incomplete survey

no-match.title: Page not found

know-yourself.name: Know yourself

1.description: Based on your self-assessment, you are taking the first steps towards better self-knowledge – great! By identifying what you are interested in and what motivates you, you can focus your energy on the right things. Remember that self-knowledge can be developed at any age, and even small steps are important.

2.description: You have already taken important steps towards a better understanding of yourself. You can assess your life events, resources, interests and values in a comprehensive way. This is a good foundation to build on and develop yourself. Remember that self-knowledge is an ongoing process. Every step you take will advance your personal growth and development. Good luck on your journey!

3.description: You are already well aware of your strengths, values and motivations. Continue exploring your experiences, values and feelings. This will help you better understand how they affect your choices and actions in different situations. Remember that self-knowledge is an ongoing process that develops and deepens throughout life. Good luck!

4.description: The results of your self-assessment show a good sense of self-knowledge and the ability to manage yourself. You have a strong foundation on which to build your future – keep up the good work! Remember that self-knowledge is an ongoing process that develops and deepens throughout life.

my-life-story.name: My life story
my-life-story.info: Understanding your story and experiences will help you to better understand yourself and your choices.

1.title: I understand myself and can talk about the important experiences in my life.

resources-and-ability-to-work.name: Resources and working capacity
resources-and-ability-to-work.info: Resources are things that help you cope with everyday life and face life’s challenges. They can be physical, psychological, social or spiritual. Work capacity refers to the balance between resources and work demands.

1.title: When I plan my career, I think about my life situation and health.

2.title: I know how to make sure I have the energy to do my job.

feelings-and-ways-of-acting.name: Feelings and ways of working

1.title: I understand how my feelings influence what I do and the choices I make.

feelings-and-ways-of-acting.info: Emotions give us important information about the environment, other people and ourselves. Emotions guide action and are part of perception and thinking. Almost all human activity involves emotions.

values.name: Values

1.title: I know what matters to me.

values.info: When you know what is important to you, it is easier to focus on what matters. Knowing your values helps you make decisions and set and achieve goals.

motivational-factors.name: Motivational factors

1.title: I know what inspires me.

2.title: I know how to improve my enthusiasm.

motivational-factors.info: Motivational factors are things that inspire or encourage you to do something. They help you achieve your goals.

interests.name: Interests

1.title: I know what interests me.

interests.info: Being aware of your interests helps you plan your career. Being interested in something encourages you to learn new things and work towards your goals.

attitude-towards-work-and-studying.name: Attitudes to work and study
attitude-towards-work-and-studying.info: When work or study feels meaningful to you, it can improve your wellbeing. The importance of work and study may change over the course of your life. You can also find new ways to think about them and get more out of them!

1.title: I have a positive attitude to work and study.
Learn to describe and structure your important life events
1.feedback: Great! You have now practised describing and structuring your major life events. Outlining your life story will deepen your self-knowledge. Understanding your experiences and values will help you make the career choices you want to make.

0.title: Write down 3–5 important life events you have had below.
0.description: For example: starting studies, graduating, starting a new job, moving to a new city, the ups and downs of life, an important relationship, starting a family.

1.title: Choose one major life event and think about how it affected your life and the changes it brought.
1.description: For example: “Starting a new job made me excited and gave me new learning opportunities. It provided me with the opportunity to use and develop my skills. Changing jobs meant moving to a new city and adapting to a new working environment. New colleagues and new exercises also led to new networks.”

2.description:
Write down your main life events and stages in the text boxes below, each event in its own box.
For example: studies, work, the ups and downs of life, an important relationship, a new family member.

● Choose descriptive emojis for the events that affect your current career plans and professional choices, i.e., the choices you are currently making at work or in studies.
● Select one of the events you highlighted and use the text box to describe how the event impacts your current situation. Is the impact positive or negative? Can you impact the situation yourself? Are there things about the situation that you have no control over, such as other people’s feelings, decisions or external circumstances?
2.title: Learn how to assess the impact of major events on the present and identify yourpossibilities to make an impact
2.subtitle: Life events and stages
2.feedback: Great! Digging into your life story will deepen your self-knowledge. Reviewing major events and choices and assessing their impact will help you identify how you can influence the present and the future.

3.feedback: Discuss the results of the exercise with a friend or someone close to you. They can offer new perspectives and help you understand how you can actively impact your future. Remember that your life story is a unique resource that you can use to plan your career and achieve your goals.
3.description:
Use the text boxes to write down, in chronological order, 5–10 significant life events or decisions that have shaped your life so far.
For example: stages in your studies, jobs, volunteering, the ups and downs of life, important relationships, other significant events.

● Choose an emoji that describes each event.
● See if there are any recurring themes in your life events.
● Choose one significant life event and analyse it in more detail: How did the event influence your subsequent life events and choices? How did the event affect your goals and dreams? Did you learn something from the experience that can help you in the future? Write down your most important thought in the text box.
3.subtitle: Life events and stages
3.title: Use your life story to learn to predict how your choices will affect your future

1.title: Learn to identify what creates stress and what reinforces your resources
What makes you tired? From the list below, choose things that feel draining and burdening for you:

2.title: What makes you feel good? From the list below, choose things that give you strength and energy:

1.after-title: Take a moment to think about what brings you the most joy, i.e., what is your most important resource of all?
1.feedback: Well done! You have now practised identifying the things that stress you and the things that function as resources. Resources are things that make your work easier, inspire and motivate you, and boost your energy.

2.title: Learn how to assess the burden created by work, studies and everyday life. Make an action plan to reduce the burden
2.feedback: Well done! You have now practised assessing the burden created by work, studies and everyday life and to plan measures to reduce them. Resources are things that make your work easier, inspire and motivate you, and boost your energy.

1.title: What inspires you and makes you feel good? Write your answer below.
1.description:
For example:
“Importance and impact of work or studies”
“Recognition and reward for achievements”
“Opportunity to learn new skills and develop”
“Positive and supportive work or study environment”
“Opportunity to work independently and make my own decisions”
“Clear and achievable goals”
“Constructive and regular feedback”
“Hobbies”
“Travelling and new experiences”
“Time spent with friends and family”
“Volunteering and community”

2.title: What burdens you or challenges you? Write your answer below.
2.description:
For example: 
“Excessive strain and too much work or studying”
“Unclear or conflicting expectations and goals”
“Negative or stifling work or study atmosphere”
“Insufficient support and guidance from supervisors or teachers”
“Tight schedules and constant rush”
“Difficulty in finding a balance between work/studies and free time”
“Monotonous and repetitive exercises with no variety”
“Excessive scheduling”
“Social pressure”
“Excessive screen time”
“Hobbies becoming responsibilities”
“Holiday stress”
“Loneliness”
“Financial pressures”
“Lack of sleep”

3.title: Choose one thing that burdens or challenges you and set at least one concrete goal to reduce your stress.
3.description: For example: “I want to learn how to schedule better”, “I want to learn how to talk about my grievances”, “I want to learn to tolerate uncertainty better”, “I want to find more effective study techniques”.

4.title: Below, write at least one measure or step you will take to reduce the burden.
4.description: For example: “I will learn to prioritise”, “I will take a mindfulness course”, “I will try new study techniques, such as mind maps.”

1.title: Learn to recognise your feelings and how they affect your actions
1.feedback: Excellent! You have now practised recognising and articulating the impact of your feelings and moods on your actions. Recognising and managing our feelings helps us cope with difficult situations, communicate better with others and make sensible decisions.

1.title: Below, write down what you are feeling right now.
1.description: Feelings can include: joy, love, affection, sadness, fear, anger, disgust, anxiety, gratitude, shame, hope, happiness, contentment, pleasure, courage, relaxed.

2.title: Choose one of the feelings you listed above and think about what made you feel this way.
2.description: For example: “I feel stressed because I have a lot to do today”, “I feel happy because I received positive feedback for my work”.

3.title: Think about how this feeling affects your actions.
3.description: For example: “Stress makes me feel like I cannot concentrate properly on my exercises”, “Happiness makes me feel motivated and energetic”.

4.title: Think about what you can do to process the feeling.
4.description: For example: “Stress: I can make a list of my exercises and start with one thing at a time”, “Happiness: I will continue to work with the same enthusiasm and keep in mind the positive feedback I received”.

2.title: Learn to understand your feelings and anticipate their impact on your actions

1.title: Below, write down what you are feeling right now.
1.description: For example: joy, love, affection, sadness, fear, anger, disgust, anxiety, gratitude, shame, hope, happiness, contentment, pleasure, courage, relaxed.

2.title: Choose one of the feelings and analyse it in more detail: Think about why you feel this way. What situation or thought triggered this feeling?
2.description: For example: “I am excited because I received good feedback for my work and I feel that my contribution matters.”

3.title: Below, think about and evaluate what the long-term effects of continuing to feel this way could have on you.
3.description: For example: “The feeling: enthusiasm. If the enthusiasm continues in the long term, it can have a positive impact on my motivation and creativity. I will feel energised and motivated to take on new projects and goals. On the other hand, if I cannot control my enthusiasm, it can lead me to take on too much. “

4.title: Below, write down your thoughts on how you will act on the basis of your reflection above.
4.description: For example: “The feeling: enthusiasm. I will use this positive energy to start a new project. I will remember to balance everything so that the feeling remains a sustainable resource instead of a burden.”

2.feedback: You have done a great job of reflecting on how your feelings have influenced your actions and decision-making. This introspection is important because it helps you recognise the role of feelings in your life and career management.

1.title: Learn to recognise your values
1.feedback: Excellent! You have now practised identifying and structuring your values. Values are important because they provide the basis for sustainable choices, actions and motivation. Knowing our values helps us steer in the right direction. If there is a conflict between your values and your actions, it can cause stress and difficulties.

1.title: What is important to you in life? Select the things that matter to you from the list:

1.afterText: Take a moment to think about which of these are your top three values. Write them down on paper or in the notes app on your phone. Read them again from time to time, especially at a time of important decisions, to remind yourself of what matters to you.

2.title: Learn to clarify the meaning of values in your life
2.feedback: You did a great job as you reflected on the importance of values in your life. Values can change throughout life; clarifying our values from time to time helps us act in accordance with them. Values are strongly linked to motivation: when your career plans are aligned with your values, you are more motivated and committed. This helps you cope in difficult times and make long-term decisions.

1.title: Below, write down 5–10 of your values, i.e., things that are important to you.
1.description: For example: honesty, equality, family orientation, health, hard work, modesty, naturalness, independence, creativity, responsibility, etc.

2.title: Rank your values in order of importance.
2.description: Think about which values are the most important to you and which are slightly less important. You can use these questions to help you organise your values: How is this value reflected in my life? Why is this value important to me?

3.title: Choose a value you would like to reinforce or bring out more in your life.

4.title: Below, write down some concrete actions and goals that will help you make your chosen value more visible in your daily life.
4.description: For example: “Family orientation: Set aside time each week for family activities”, “Health: Plan a weekly exercise programme and stick to a healthy diet”, “Honesty: Practise open and honest communication in all relationships”, “Friendship: Organise regular meetings with friends and keep in touch”, “Learning: Set a target of reading one book a month and attending courses or seminars”.

1.title: Learn to identify what motivates you
1.emojiTitle: Choose an emoji for each situation.
1.feedback: Great! You have now practised identifying your motivational factors, i.e., things that influence your desire and ability to achieve your goals. Identifying your motivational factors is important in order for you to understand what drives you to act in a certain way. By understanding what motivates you, you can make better decisions and plan your career with a sense of purpose.
1.description:
In the text boxes below, write down 3–4 everyday situations that brought you excitement, joy or satisfaction. Answer the following questions for each situation:
What were you doing?
Who was with you?
Where were you?

2.title: Learn how to combine motivational factors with career planning
2.description: Look at the lists below and think about what motivates you internally and what motivates you externally.
2.feedback: Well done! You have now practised identifying what motivates you and anticipating how you can maintain your motivation. Your motivational factors are an asset that will help you succeed at work and in life in general. Motivational factors depend on many factors, such as life stage, learning or working environment and achievements. The most important thing is to identify your motivational factors so that you can make good decisions and focus your efforts in the right direction.

1.title: What motivates you internally? Below, reflect on your most important internal motivator.
1.description:
For example:
I want to help others.
I enjoy learning new things.
I get satisfaction from solving problems.
I want to develop professionally.
Work makes me feel like I matter.
I enjoy the creativity that work brings.
I want to realise my values and passions.
Something else, what?

2.title: What motivates you externally? Below, reflect on your most important external motivator.
2.description:
For example:
I want financial stability.
Rewards (bonuses, promotions).
Good working conditions and benefits.
I want to achieve professional status or prestige.
Safety in the workplace.
I want positive feedback and recognition.
I work to support my family or loved ones.
Something else, what?

3.title: Below, write down one work or study-related goal, and think about how the motivational factors you have considered above can help you achieve this goal.
3.description: Example: “I will choose an internship where I can help people and develop my skills for my career development.”

1.title: Learn to identify and share your interests
1.feedback: Well done! Hopefully you had some new ideas about the importance of interests in your everyday life. It is useful to reflect on your interests comprehensively in the different areas of your life. Reflecting on what we are genuinely interested in might help us structure, plan and prioritise our time and resources better or fine-tune our work.

1.title: Below, write down three things you like to do in your free time or at work/studies.
1.description: Example: “I like playing computer games”, “I enjoy teamwork”, “I like strategy games”, “I like writing”, “I enjoy being in nature”, “I like fixing cars”.

2.title: Choose one of these things and think about why it interests you.
2.description: Example: “I like playing computer games because they challenge me strategically and give me the opportunity to get better all the time”, “I like writing because it helps me structure my thoughts and express myself.”

3.title: Write one sentence about your interest and what it means to you.
3.description: Example: “Playing computer games develops my problem-solving skills and challenges me, which inspires me to constantly improve my performance”, “Writing is a way for me to structure my thoughts and express my creativity”.

2.description:
In the below text boxes, write down 3–5 things you enjoy the most in your free time.
For example: “Reading, drawing, exercise, music, organising parties, handicrafts, travelling.”

● Choose descriptive emojis for each item.
● Then connect your interests to your skills: in each text box, reflect on what kind of skills you use in your interests.
For example: “Reading - analytical skills, Drawing - creativity, Party planning - organisational skills, Exercise - teamwork.”
● Think about how you could use these interests and skills (more) at work, in your studies or in your everyday life? Write down ideas for each area of interest.
For example: “Drawing - creativity: I can use my creativity to develop visual presentations, such as infographics or marketing materials that make complex information easier to understand”, “Party planning - organisational skills: I can use my organisational skills to plan and coordinate events, meetings or projects at work or school, making sure everything runs smoothly and on time.”
2.title: Learn to use your interests
2.feedback: Well done! It is useful to reflect on your interests comprehensively in the different areas of your life. What interests us is what drives us to develop our skills and invest our time and other resources. Interests are a source of inspiration and motivation and are often linked to our other strengths in some way.

1.title: Learn to identify and talk about your approach to work and study
1.description: Think of someone you respect or admire and who inspires you. The person can be real or fictional, for example, a movie character. Answer the following questions on the basis of the person you have chosen:
1.feedback: Good reflections! Identifying your attitude to work and studying is important for career management. Identifying your attitudes will help you find the paths that suit you the best. By understanding how you approach work and studies, you can use your attitude as a competitive advantage – and develop these qualities, if necessary. A positive attitude and commitment are competitive advantages!

1.title: How do you think the person deals with challenges and adversity?
1.description: For example: “The person accepts challenges with enthusiasm and sees adversity as an opportunity to learn.”

2.title: What kind of a mindset or attitude does the person have towards work and studying?
2.description: For example: “The person is motivated and puts their whole personality into their work. They are also always ready to help others.”

3.title: Which characteristics or experiences do you share with the character? What kind of differences do you notice?
3.description: For example: “We both have a desire to learn new things. The difference is that the person is calmer than I am in the face of adversity.”

2.title: Learn how to analyse and develop your attitude to work and studying
2.feedback: Well done! Analysing and developing your attitudes is important for career management. By understanding your attitude to work and studies, you can use your attitude to your advantage and develop it in a goal-oriented manner. Remember that changing your attitude takes time, so be kind to yourself – and celebrate even the small steps forward! P.S. To see your progress, complete regular self-assessments in the future to see if your attitude towards work and studies has changed or if you have achieved your goals in terms of developing your attitude!

1.title: Below, describe your attitude to work and/or studying.
1.description: For example: “My work gives me enthusiasm and satisfaction. Sometimes it also stresses me because of the tight schedules.”

2.title: Think about what your attitude to work and/or studying would be like in an ideal situation.
2.description: For example: “Motivated and enthusiastic. I would be able to maintain a positive energy even in challenging situations.”

3.title: Below, write down the goals you are currently working and/or studying towards.
3.description: For example: “To complete a specific task or project within a deadline”, “To complete a course or learn a new skill within a specific time frame”, “To develop time-management skills and reduce stress.”

4.title: Below, write down the types of measures that would contribute to your wellbeing and the achievement of your goals.
4.description: For example: “Take care of my work-life balance. Set aside time for hobbies and relaxation to recover and recharge my batteries”, “Use to-do lists and a calendar to track my progress and prioritise the most important exercises.”

know-yourself.info: Self-knowledge is the basis for effective career planning. When you know yourself, what you are interested in, what is important to you, what you are passionate about and how you feel about things, you will be better able to identify the right career path for you.

competence-first.name: Competence first

1.description:
It is easier to see your skills through concrete successes. Think back to a time when you were successful, received good feedback or felt proud of yourself.

Watch Sitra’s video on making your competencies visible <0>https://youtu.be/B6kkPl73i8s

1.title: Write down 2–4 of your successes or achievements.
1.description: Successes can be related to everyday life, studies, relationships, hobbies, work or anything else in life.  Do not be shy or self-critical; list everything that comes to mind.

2.title: While you are at it, think about the strengths you used to achieve your successes.
2.description: (e.g. reliability, responsibility, flexibility, cheerfulness, sociability, willingness to learn, creativity...)

2.title: Learn to structure your competence and strengths
2.feedback: We are so glad that you have thought about these issues! Identifying your competence and strengths are important steps in your personal development. It is also important to understand that the skills needed in the working life are constantly changing – so keep yourself updated on the skills that will be needed in the future!

1.title: Write down 5–7 of your strengths.
1.description: Strengths include character traits or features. You can use the VIA strength test at <0>www.viacharacter.org</0> if you need help.  If you want to change the language, select your desired language from the Google Translate bar.

2.title: Write down 2–4 examples of the skills you have and how you have used them.
2.description:
Competence is gained through everyday life, work, studies and hobbies. Competence includes all the various skills you use in your life. 
For example, “I can cook or bake”, “I can stream”, “I can update social media”, “I can work in a team”, “I understand the needs of customers”, “I can manage myself and my work.“

3.description: Certain skills help us succeed, especially in the working life. Different sectors and jobs need slightly different skill sets, and competence needs are also changing.

1.description: You can use the VIA strength test at <0>www.viacharacter.org</0> if you need help.  If you want to change the language, select your desired language from the Google Translate bar.

2.title: Write down the skills/competencies that are your core competencies.
2.description: Think about these skills in the context of a changing working life. Which skills do you need to develop?

1.title: Learn how to use your skills in different situations
1.feedback: Amazing! You found that the skills you have can be used in various contexts. There are different types of generic skills that are needed for a wide range of jobs and professions. You acquire these skills throughout life, even outside the classroom.
1.description:
Your strengths and skills can often be used in a variety of situations. You may have learned to be a good listener from friends, for example, but listening skills are also useful at work.

Think of a skill, competence or attribute that you have.
Different kinds of skills and competencies may include, for example: Creativity Systematicity Cultural competence Initiative Critical thinking Interpersonal skills Reading long texts Leadership Perseverance Integrity Humility Asking for advice Self-control Cooperative skills Self-management Playfulness Dexterity Digital skills Aesthetics Communication skills Flexibility Learning skills Speed Listening Self-development Cautiousness Sporty Working in a group Accurate Sense of taste Bravery Good memory Writing Fairness Drawing Curiosity Keeping a schedule Entrepreneurial Anticipation Empathy Toughness Problem-solving Teamwork Project management.

1.title: Write down examples of how you have used/could use your chosen skill or competence in different situations.
1.description: For example, if you chose “project management”. You could describe the use of the skill in the workplace in the following manner: “I led a team that developed new software on time and on budget.”   The same skill in volunteering could be: “I organised a local event with over 100 participants.”  In a hobby, this skill can be seen as follows: “I designed and implemented a garden project that required careful scheduling and resource management.”

2.title: Learn to see your skills from various perspectives
2.description: You can use your competence and skills in various situations and jobs. Reflect on your skills from different perspectives.
2.feedback: Keep developing yourself, build on your strengths and be open to new opportunities. Network, learn new things and be brave. You already have a lot of knowledge, and you are always gaining more. Have the courage to use it in different situations. You have potential, and you can achieve your dreams! Remember that your career is a journey, and every step teaches you something valuable. Dare to dream big and trust yourself.

1.title: Describe your professional, i.e., hard skills.
1.description: Professional or hard skills refer to knowledge acquired through education and work experience that is related to one’s profession or work.

2.title: Write down the generic skills you have.
2.description: For example: knowledge of sustainable development principles, interaction and communication skills, problem-solving skills, creativity, the ability to learn, managing the big picture, multicultural skills, self-direction, ethical behaviour, information management and analytical skills.

3.title: Write down the general working life skills, i.e., transferable skills, you have.
3.description: For example: digital skills, language skills, empathy, adaptability and critical thinking.

4.title: Choose one of the skills and write down how you could apply it in different situations. Briefly describe how you could use your chosen skill in three different situations.

1.title: Learn to identify your development areas
1.feedback: Well done! You have identified your development areas. Recognising them is important when setting goals for yourself. The next step is to make a plan where you set small, concrete goals for yourself, such as reading a book or taking an online course – and then, get to work!

1.title: Write down 1–3 skills or competencies that, if developed, would help you achieve a specific goal.
1.description: For example: “Time management: Improving my time management skills would help me do my job more efficiently and reduce stress.”

2.title: Write down examples of the situations in which these developmental areas arise and how they affect your work.
2.description: For example: “Time management: This development area is particularly important on busy days, when there are many exercises to do and tight deadlines. Better time management skills help me prioritise exercises and avoid last-minute rushes, which improves the quality of my work and reduces stress.”

2.title: Set yourself an action plan to achieve your goals
2.feedback: Great! For professional and personal growth, do not limit yourself to your strengths. If you keep going for exercises that seem easy and natural, you can easily get stuck. Sometimes, it is useful to reach outside your comfort zone.

1.title: List your development areas. Think about which skills are particularly important for your career.

2.title: Set concrete goals to develop your skills.

3.title: Find out your strengths and development areas with a SWOT analysis
3.feedback: You have done a great job on the SWOT analysis! Identifying your strengths and areas you want to develop is a great step forward. This self-knowledge is valuable and will help you plan your career accordingly. The SWOT analysis is an ongoing process and updating it regularly will help you stay on the right track. Remember that every day is another opportunity to grow and develop.
3.description: Use the SWOT analysis to increase your self-knowledge and plan your career. Set aside enough time to work with the SWOT analysis. The analysis is intended to be a positive process that benefits the implementation of change. Make a SWOT analysis of your strengths and development areas.

1.title: Strengths:
1.description: List your strengths, such as your competence, skills and achievements.

2.title: Weaknesses:
2.description:
dentify areas you want to improve.  
For example: time management, networking, performing, lack of a particular skill

3.title: Opportunities:
3.description:
Think about what kind of career opportunities are out there. 
For example: growing and changing industries, rapid technological development

4.title: Threats:
4.description:
Be aware of the factors that can affect your career.  
For example: economic changes or competitive situation

1.title: Find out what you think of yourself as a learner.
1.feedback: You are on your way to self-knowledge and an understanding of who you are as a learner. Think back to how past experiences impacted your learning and how you faced challenges and celebrated successes. It is important to be aware of your strengths and learning styles. Remember to use these skills on your way to achieving your goals!
1.description: A positive view of yourself as a learner promotes learning.

1.title: What kind of feelings and thoughts does learning evoke?
1.description: Find an image that describes your feeling. Browse magazines or use search engines. Write down what the picture says about your thoughts.

2.title: Reflect on a situation in which you learnt a new skill or competence.
2.description: What helped you learn?

2.title: Learn how to develop and maintain a positive perception of yourself as a learner
2.feedback: Learning usually arouses enthusiasm and curiosity as you experience the joy of learning something new. Learning something new can also be frustrating when you face challenges. However, the sense of achievement will usually win in the end. Learning new skills and competencies also gives you confidence.
2.description: Think about some of your successful learning experiences.

1.title: What kind of feelings did learning evoke in you?

2.title: What helped you learn the new concept?

3.title: What are your strengths as a learner?
3.description: For example: “I am patient and persistent and do not give up easily when faced with difficulties”, “I have the ability to apply what I learn in practice, which helps me understand things in more depth”, “I am curious and motivated to keep learning new things, which keeps me up to date and develops my skills”.

1.title: Learn to identify how you learn new skills
1.feedback: Learning new skills is an individual process, and everyone learns in their own way. Learning new skills takes time and active engagement. Believe in your abilities and enjoy the learning journey!
1.description: Think of a specific situation in which you learnt a new skill.

1.title: What inspired and encouraged you to learn something new?

2.title: What is something around you that supported your learning?
Learn how to structure and advance your learning
2.feedback: Good reflections! Learning new skills opens doors to further learning and personal growth. Regularly reflect on your experiences and the things you have learnt. Think about how they have influenced your competence identity and your career. Keep challenging yourself and learning new things!
2.description: Everyone has their own unique ways of learning and absorbing new skills. It is important to identify which method works best for you and how much time you can spend learning. There are many ways to learn new things, such as working on new projects or taking part in courses, coaching and training. Some people like to study independently and go deeper on their own, while others benefit more from learning in a group.

1.title: Think about a skill you would like to learn.

2.title: Think about what might prevent you from learning the skill.

3.title: Think about what can help you learn the skill.
Learn to assess your learning
3.description: Everyone has their own unique ways of learning and absorbing new skills. It is important to identify which method works best for you and how much time you can spend learning. There are many ways to learn new things, such as working on new projects or taking part in courses, coaching and training. Some people like to study independently and go deeper on their own, while others benefit more from learning in a group.
3.feedback: Very good! It is important to identify your learning style and find what works best for you. Think about the surroundings and situations that best support your learning. Online courses can be a good option for independent learners, while group work can provide support and interaction. Learning is continuous, and you can combine different methods to achieve the best possible learning outcome.

1.title: Reflect on how you learn best and write down your answer.
1.description:
Evaluate a learning process that has taken place:
● Did you meet your learning objectives? Why or why not?
● What helped and what hindered the learning process?
● What kind of resources were available to you?
● What did you learn from the process? What worked? What did not work? What did you learn that you can use in the future?

1.title: Learn to recognise your competence and strengths
1.feedback: You have done a great job in identifying your strengths and applying them to different situations. Identifying your strengths and skills helps you understand yourself better and achieve your goals. Keep up the good work!

3.title: Learn how to use your competence and strengths
3.feedback: You have done an excellent job of identifying and analysing your strengths. Choosing five key strengths and reflecting on how you learnt them will help you understand how to use them in your career. As you prepare to showcase your skills, remember that each strength is a unique asset that sets you apart. Be proud of your achievements and share them proudly in job interviews and on your CV.  Keep up the good work in building a meaningful and rewarding career path for yourself. Good luck!

1.title: Write down your five main strengths and how you have used them.
I know my skills and strengths.

competence-and-strengths.name: Competence and strengths
competence-and-strengths.info: By identifying your strengths and skills, you can find life paths that suit you. Identifying your strengths will motivate and inspire you to develop your skills.

1.title: I know how to use my skills in different situations and exercises.

application-of-competence.name: Application of skills
application-of-competence.info: Applying your competence refers to using your knowledge and skills in different situations. When considering career opportunities, think extensively about where you could use your skills.

development-areas.name: Areas for improvement

1.title: I know what I should develop to achieve my goals.

development-areas.info: Once you know your areas of development, you can start working on them. Focusing on areas of development and continuous learning will often bring more enthusiasm and motivation to plan your life and career.

self-perception-as-a-learner.name: Perception of yourself as a learner

1.title: I am confident in my ability to learn and develop.

self-perception-as-a-learner.info: How you see yourself as a learner affects your learning and your attitude towards studying and working. Your perception changes and develops throughout your life. A positive perception of yourself as a learner is created through interaction with others.

learning-new-skills.name: Learning new skills

1.title: I like learning new skills.

learning-new-skills.info: You develop your skills throughout your life, for example, to improve your wellbeing, develop at work or advance in your career. Learning new skills can be purposeful and structured, but also part of everyday learning.

competence-first.info: Building a competence identity means identifying and using your strengths and skills in different situations. It will also help you realise what kind of new skills you might need and how to tell others about your skills to achieve your goal.

1.description: It is important to reflect on your strengths and areas of development. Keep going – it will help you grow and learn more! Remember to be open to new opportunities and believe in your ability to learn and develop.

2.description: You are already good at structuring your skills and strengths. Keep up the good work and remember to use concrete examples to illustrate your competence in different situations. Identifying areas of development is also important – think regularly about what you can do to improve yourself further. You have done an amazing job!

3.description: It is great that you understand your skills and strengths in relation to your areas of development. A positive approach to learning and applying new skills is important. Take care of your development. You have realised important things!

4.description: Amazing! Being able to articulate your skills is an important competence you should reflect on from time to time. Your skills can change and develop. Good luck!

ready-for-change.name: Ready for change
ready-for-change.long-name: Your future and capacity to change

dreams-and-visions.name: Dreams

1.title: I have dreams and hopes for my future

dreams-and-visions.info: Dreams and aspirations are important in planning a life and career that suit you. Dreams and aspirations keep your thoughts positive and help you achieve your goals.

problem-solving.name: Problem-solving

1.title: I can find out and resolve issues related to my education and career choices.

problem-solving.info: Problem-solving skills help you overcome challenges. They help you to be creative and find solutions. Problem-solving skills make you more flexible and adaptable.

creativity.name: Creativity

1.title: I can brainstorm and come up with different options when I think about my future.

creativity.info: Creativity is important when planning your career and your future. It helps you to be flexible when changes happen and find unique career paths. Creativity encourages people to try new things and see possibilities.

decision-making.name: Decision-making

1.title: I can make choices and decisions that are relevant to my life and career.

decision-making.info: Decision-making skills help you evaluate different options and make informed choices.

goal-setting.name: Objectives

1.title: I can set clear goals for myself.

goal-setting.info: Clearly defined objectives help you focus on what matters and make informed decisions. Sub-objectives help you outline concrete steps towards long-term goals.

preparedness.name: Preparedness

1.title: I can assess whether my plans have a chance of success and make contingency plans.

preparedness.info: Preparedness means preparing for different options and risks. This brings a sense of control.

resilience.name: Resilience

1.title: I can be flexible in the face of change and bounce back from adversity.

resilience.info: Resilience refers to the ability to adapt and cope with change and challenges. It is both mental flexibility and the ability to recover.

uncertainty-tolerance.name: Tolerating uncertainty

1.title: I have ways of tolerating uncertainty.

uncertainty-tolerance.info: Tolerance of uncertainty refers to the ability to withstand situations in which the outcome is uncertain. This skill helps you act even if you do not have all the answers.

1.title: Learn to identify your dreams and aspirations for the future
1.feedback: When you articulate your dreams, they become clearer to you. Dreams and aspirations are important when planning a meaningful life and career for yourself. They can be small or big. Dreams and aspirations help you maintain positive momentum, which in turn helps you focus on goals and learning.

1.title: Can you dream?
1.description:
Below, think about the following questions:
What would you do if you had unlimited time and money?
Which skills or abilities would you like to learn or develop?
What would you like to change in your current life?

2.title: What is your biggest dream? Write your answer below.
2.description: Examples of dreams and aspirations: travelling, owning a home, starting a family, writing a book, landing your dream job, staying healthy, maintaining close friendships, making new friends, financial stability, developing at a hobby, starting a new hobby.

2.title: Learn to visualise your dreams and aspirations for the future and work towards them
2.feedback: When you envision your dreams, you give them wings! Dreams and aspirations are important when planning a meaningful life and career for yourself. Dreams and aspirations help you maintain positive momentum, which in turn helps you focus on goals and learning.

1.title: Below, write down 3–5 things you would like to see in your future.
1.description: They can be related to your career, personal life, hobbies, travel or relationships.

2.title: From your list, choose one future dream that you would like to visualise. Then, close your eyes and imagine what your life will look like when this dream has come true.
2.description:
Where are you and what are you doing?
Who is around you?
How do you feel?
What have you achieved?

3.title: Consider how you can maintain your motivation on your way towards the future you just visualised.
3.description:
You can use the following questions to help you:
How can you reward yourself for small steps forward?
How can you keep yourself motivated when you face challenges?
How can you make use of your support network (e.g. family, friends, mentors)?

1.title: Learn to develop your problem-solving skills
1.feedback: Problem-solving skills help you face challenges and overcome them effectively. They help you be creative and find solutions. Problem-solving skills also promote flexibility and adaptability in changing situations, which is particularly important in an ever-changing world.

2.title: Learn how to find solutions to questions about education and career choices
2.feedback: Problem-solving skills help you face challenges and overcome them effectively. They help you be creative and find solutions. Problem-solving skills also promote flexibility and adaptability in changing situations, which is particularly important in an ever-changing world.

1.title: Choose a challenge you have encountered at work or in your studies.
1.description:
Choose a specific situation with a clear problem that you have not yet solved it in a fully satisfactory way.
For example: “Lack of motivation: I have been struggling to find the motivation to study for a course that does not interest me. I have not yet figured out how to get myself excited about it.”

2.title:
Reflect on the challenge using the following questions and write your answers below: 
What exactly is the problem? 
When and where does it occur? 
Who is involved or contributes to the solution? 
Why is it important to solve the problem?
2.description: For example: “Lack of motivation: I cannot find the motivation to study for a course that does not interest me. This makes it difficult to concentrate on studying and finish my homework. The problem occurs especially when I try to do course-related exercises at home. People involved in solving the problem can include: myself, the teacher, fellow students, family and friends. It is important to solve this problem, because due to a lack of motivation, I cannot complete the course or graduate. This also affects my self-esteem.”

3.title: Come up with three different solutions.
3.description:
Consider both traditional and unconventional approaches. You can list even some crazy ideas.
For example: “Lack of motivation: 1. I will reward myself for completing the project with something special, like a movie night or a weekend trip. 2. I will get support from fellow students: Studying together can make the subject more interesting. 3. I will read articles, watch videos or listen to podcasts related to the subject of the course.”

4.title: Choose the most feasible option and think about what you need to implement this solution.
4.description: For example: help from others, more time, money, space, equipment, etc.

3.title: Learn to anticipate the consequences of your decisions
3.feedback: Problem-solving skills help you face challenges and overcome them effectively. They help you be creative and find solutions. Problem-solving skills also promote flexibility and adaptability in changing situations, which is particularly important in an ever-changing world.

1.title: Select a problem relevant to your career that you have faced or may face in the future.

2.title: Come up with least three different possible solutions to the problem.

3.title: Choose one of the solutions. Imagine and write down the possible consequences of your chosen solution.
3.description: Think about the positive and negative effects the solution could have on your work, studies and everyday life.

4.title: Think about what could prevent you from implementing the solution you have chosen. Could you prepare for it in advance?

1.title: Choose a specific problem you often face and write it below.
1.description: For example: “I am often late”, “I often forget to do my homework”, “I am nervous about performing”, “I cannot find the time to exercise.”

2.title: Think of three different solutions to your problem.

2.afterText:
Choose the most feasible solution. After you have tried the solution for a few days, be sure to assess the situation:
Has the problem been solved? What worked and what did not?

1.title: Learn to develop alternatives
1.feedback: Well done! Creative brainstorming encourages people to try new things and see new and surprising possibilities. Creativity is important when planning your career and future!

1.title: Below, list things you are interested in or passionate about.

2.title: Consider how your interests and passions could relate to different kinds of career opportunities: Below, write down the first profession or role that comes to mind.
2.description: This is usually the most familiar and obvious option.

3.title: Next, list as many new and different career possibilities as you can in five minutes.
3.description: Do not judge or criticise ideas at this stage, focus on quantity and creativity.

4.title: Go through the ideas you came up with. Did the assignment give you new ideas as you reflect on your career?

2.title: Learn to plan creatively for the future
2.feedback: Creativity is a key asset in planning your career and future as it helps you adapt to changing situations and find unique career paths. Creativity is the key to continuous learning and growth.

1.title: Below, write down 3–5 goals you want to achieve in the next five years.

2.title: Select one of the goals. Write down any possible obstacles that could prevent you from achieving this goal.

3.title: Next, imagine various ways you can overcome or get around these obstacles.  Use a creative method, such as a mind map, the six thinking hats or brainstorming, to help you come up with ideas.
3.description: Below, note down the creative method you used as well as ways you can overcome any obstacles to achieving your goal.

3.title: Learn to anticipate creatively
3.feedback: Creativity is a key asset in planning your career and future as it helps you adapt to changing situations and find unique career paths. Creativity is the key to continuous learning and growth.

1.title: Choose one possible future change or phenomenon that has or may have an impact on your career. Next, imagine and describe three possible scenarios (= alternative descriptions for the course of events), each in its own box, that the phenomenon could develop into over the next five years:

2.title: a. Optimistic scenario where everything goes in the best possible way.

3.title: b. A realistic scenario based on current information and the most likely outcomes.

4.title: c. A pessimistic scenario where things do not go as desired.

3.afterText: Finally, take a moment to think about what you can do now to prepare for each scenario.

1.title: Learn to identify factors that influence your decision-making
1.feedback: Great! Decision-making skills help you identify and evaluate various options, weigh their benefits and risks and make informed choices.  Decision-making skills also include the ability to assess consequences. Decision-making skills can be developed through practice.

1.title: Below, write down three decisions you have made recently.
1.description: For example: “I chose what to eat for lunch”, “I decided how to spend my free time”, ”I chose what to wear today”, “I chose which task to do first”, “I chose whether to attend a meeting remotely or in person”.

2.title: Think about what influenced these decisions.
2.description: For example: “I chose lunch based on the fact that it was the only vegetarian option in the workplace cafeteria”, “I chose to spend my free time with a specific hobby because it relaxes me”, “I chose these clothes because I know my friends wear the same style”, “I chose the project based on its importance and deadline”, “I chose to do my homework quickly so that I would have more free time”, “I chose to attend a meeting remotely because I can concentrate better without the distractions of the office.”

3.title: Examine your answer above: Below, list the factors that stand out to you. Which factors influenced your decision-making?
3.description: For example: “Health”, “Comfort”, “Time savings”, “Mood”, “Other people’s opinions/expectations”, “Schedules”, “Priorities”, “Personal energy level”.

2.title: Learn how to make informed decisions

1.title: Below, write a decision relevant to your studies or career that you are currently facing or may face in the future.
1.description: For example: “Choosing an institution or field of study”, “Deciding on further studies, such as a Master’s degree or PhD”, “Decide which company or organisation to work for”, “Choosing between different jobs or roles”, “Deciding to acquire new skills or certificates that can contribute to my career”, “Deciding to change my field of work or change to another profession”, “Choice between remote work and office work”, “Decision to participate in professional networking events and conferences”, “Decide how much time and energy to devote to work versus personal life”

2.title: Below, think about the kind of information you need to make your decision and why.
2.description: For example: “The decision to move to another city for work: The information I need: Cost of living and housing options in the new city, commuting distance and availability of public transport, quality of life and recreational activities in the new city. Why: I want to make sure that the move makes financial sense and that I can find a suitable apartment. I want to know that my commute is reasonable and that public transport works well. I want to ensure that the new city offers good quality of life and recreational activities.”

3.title: Below, think about where you can find the information you need to support your decision-making.
3.description: For example: “The decision to move to another city for work: Official city websites, housing portals, cost calculators, public transport route guides, map services, local news and events sites, social media and forums, local groups in which I can ask for advice and experiences.”

2.feedback: Great! Decision-making skills help you identify and evaluate various options, weigh their benefits and risks and make informed choices.  Decision-making skills also include the ability to assess consequences. Decision-making skills can be developed through practice.

1.title: Learn how to set goals for yourself
1.feedback: Great! Clearly defined goals help you focus on what matters and make informed decisions. Partial goals help you outline concrete steps towards long-term goals.

1.title: Below, write down one goal that is important to you personally.
1.description: For example: “I want to improve my physical fitness”, “I want to improve my presentation skills”, “I want to improve my test scores”.

2.title: Below, write down why this goal is important to you and how it will improve your life.
2.description: For example: “Being in better shape helps me cope better in everyday life and improves my general wellbeing”, “Better presentation skills help me communicate the results of a project more effectively”, “Better grades improve my chances of getting the job I want after graduation”.

3.title: Define the objective in more detail and set a time limit.
3.description: For example: “I want to run five kilometres without breaks in three months”, “I want to be confident when I present the final report of the project in a seminar in one month”, “I want to improve my grade in the next exam by one grade”.

4.title: Break the goal down into smaller, more manageable parts.
4.description: For example: “Performance skills: Weeks 1–2: Prepare the content of the presentation. Week 3: Practise my performance in front of a mirror. Week 4: Give the presentation to colleagues and ask for feedback”, “Test scores: Weeks 1–2: Make a reading plan and divide the material into daily chunks. Week 3: Practise old exam questions. Week 4: Pick the hardest topics and give myself a practice test.”

2.title: Learn how to do career planning to support your goals
2.feedback: Great! Clearly defined goals help you focus on what matters and make informed decisions. Remember, there are many ways to reach the finish line! Think about how you can adapt your plans if you face obstacles.

1.title: Below, write down one concrete goal you want to achieve at work or in your studies.
1.description: For example: “I want to have a promotion at my current job.”

2.title: Below, write down why this goal is important to you and how it will improve your life.

3.title: List the skills and resources you need to achieve your goal.
3.description: For example: “I need leadership skills”, “I need more experience in project management”.

4.title: Below, write down the concrete steps you will take to achieve the goal.
4.description: For example: “I will attend management training next month”, “I will apply for project management exercises at my current job”.

5.title: Set a time limit for each step and monitor your progress.
5.description: For example: “Management training completed by the end of the year,” “First project management assignment completed within three months”.

1.title: Learn to identify risks
1.feedback: Preparation in career management refers to consciously preparing for various options. Thinking about the chances of a plan succeeding and preparing for risks gives a sense of control.
1.emojiTitle: Choose descriptive emojis for each item
1.description:
Each in its own text box, list 3–5 potential risks you may face at work or in your studies.
For example: “Schedule management”, “Technology malfunctions”, “Health problems”, “Conflicts with work colleagues or study friends”, “Problems with data security”

How likely are the risks to come true? Can you think of ways to manage or reduce the risks? Write at least one way to manage each risk in the text box in question.
For example: Schedule management – Use a calendar and set reminders for important exercises.

These can be related to your career, studies, personal life or finances, for example. For each risk, consider the questions below:
Why is the risk possible?
Potential consequences if the risk materialises.
1.title: Below, write down three possible changes or risks you might face in the next year.

2.title: Choose one of the changes or risks you described above and think about how you can prepare for it. Below, think about possible measures you can take to reduce the likelihood of the risk materialising or its impact.
Learn how to make a contingency plan
2.feedback: Preparation in career management refers to consciously preparing for various options. Thinking about the chances of a plan succeeding and preparing for risks gives a sense of control.

1.title: Learn how to develop resilience when life changes
1.feedback: Life is constantly changing, and resilience helps you adapt to new situations and environments. Resilience is the ability to adapt and cope with change and challenges. It means both mental flexibility and the ability to recover.

1.title: Below, write down 1–3 changes in your life that have had a significant impact on you.
1.description: For example: new job, change in job duties, dismissal or temporary lay-off, moving, graduation, new study programme, interruption of studies, new family member, illness, change in relationships, exchange abroad.

2.title: Select one of the changes you listed above and describe how you reacted to that change.
2.description: For example: “New job: I felt excited about my dream job but, at the same time, I felt stressed and uncertain about the new exercises: I did not dare ask my superiors or colleagues for advice.”

3.title: Below, think about what was useful in your reaction and what was not.

4.title: Below, write down one way you could be more flexible in responding to similar changes in the future.
4.description: For example: “I will seek more support and advice from colleagues”, “I will network with other students”.

2.title: Learn how to strengthen resilience
2.feedback: Good! Developing and maintaining resilience is worth the effort! The importance of exercise, a healthy diet and social support cannot be overemphasised when talking about resilience. Remember to reward yourself for your achievements!

1.title: elow, write down five skills, strengths or character traits that support your resilience, i.e. your ability to cope with and adapt to changes and risks.
1.description: For example: problem-solving skills, good time management skills, communication skills, adaptability, self-control, perseverance, empathy, optimism, creativity, self-confidence, flexibility, determination, critical thinking, self-compassion, networking.

2.title: How do you maintain and develop your resilience? Write your answer below.
2.description: For example: exercise, healthy diet, adequate sleep, social support, mindfulness and meditation, scheduling and prioritising, relaxation techniques, positive thinking, goal setting, rewarding myself

1.title: Learn to recognise how you deal with uncertainty
1.emojiTitle: Choose descriptive emojis for each situation
1.feedback: Tolerance of uncertainty is the ability to withstand situations in which the outcome or next steps are not clear. It is a skill that helps you act, even if you do not have all the answers.
1.description:
In the text boxes below, write down 1–3 situations in which you felt insecure in the last month.
For example: “Unclear job exercises”, “Insecurities related to studies, such as exam results”, ”Changes in relationships”, ”Income/financial challenges”.

Choose one of these situations and describe in the text box how you reacted to the uncertainty in question: What kind of feelings did you have (e.g. fear, anxiety, stress, confusion)? How did these feelings affect your behaviour?

2.title: Learn to develop your tolerance of uncertainty
2.feedback: Tolerance of uncertainty is the ability to withstand situations in which the outcome or next steps are not clear. It is a skill that helps you act, even if you do not have all the answers.   Try out the plan you just made, and reflect on your experience: think about what you learnt from this process and how you can apply what you learnt in the future.

1.title: Below, describe one situation related to work or study in which you felt insecure recently.
1.description: For example: “Unclear job exercises”, “Insecurities related to studies, such as exam results”, ”Job interview”, ”Personnel changes at work”.

2.title: Describe how you reacted when you felt insecure.

3.title: Below, write down three ways for how you could react more flexibly in similar uncertain situations in the future.
3.description: For example: “I will discuss unclear work exercises openly with my team.”

4.title: Choose one of the new approaches you listed above and make a plan for how you will try it to see if it works in practice.
4.description: For example: “I am unsure what is expected of me in terms of the new work project: I will discuss the situation openly with my colleagues and ask my manager for clarification, if necessary.”

ready-for-change.info: Imagining and dreaming about your future is important in planning your life and career. Creativity will help you develop new ideas and solutions, and informed and justified decisions will support your long-term goals. Taking risks into account and making contingency plans will help you cope with unexpected situations and maintain a positive attitude in the face of change.

1.description: Identifying your dreams and aspirations is important, as they will guide you towards your goals. Setting goals and working towards them is a key part of career management. Identifying the factors that influence your decision-making will help you make informed choices. Keep up the good work! You are on the right track towards developing your career management skills.

2.description: Good! You seem to be able to think about your future and the factors that influence it. Structuring information will help you find solutions in even the most difficult situations. In addition, your ability to see different perspectives and evaluate alternatives will certainly help you in your decision-making. Decision-making skills are worth practising.

3.description: You are a versatile and skilful thinker! You can assess alternatives from various angles and are prepared to face change and risk. It is great to see that you can find unusual solutions and new possibilities. Creativity opens doors to new paths. Keep pursuing your goals bravely – you are on the right track! Check out the tips below for the next steps!

4.description: Excellent! You seem to be very good at thinking in a variety of ways and understanding extensive connections. You can assess alternatives from various angles and are prepared to face change and risk. Keep in mind that there is always room for learning and development in life. Good luck on your journey!

world-around-you.name: The world around you

opportunities-and-constraints.name: Opportunities and boundary conditions

1.title: I can seize opportunities that suit my situation and take into account any constraints.

opportunities-and-constraints.info: Opportunities refer to alternative paths and opportunities offered by life. Preconditions are constraints that affect your decisions or plans. These can include your health, where you live and the labour market situation.

labor-market.name: Labour market

1.title: I can identify changes and opportunities in the labour market that may affect my situation.

labor-market.info: Labour market data tell you what kind of job opportunities are available and what the job situation is like in different sectors. Knowing the labour market will help you direct your career in a goal-oriented manner.

education-and-learning.name: Education and studying

1.title: I can look for training and study opportunities that suit my situation.

education-and-learning.info: At different stages of your life and career, you can train and study in different ways. This can mean learning new skills, further training or even learning a new field altogether. Continuous learning not only improves your professional skills, but also opens up new opportunities.

social-structures.name: Structures of society

1.title: I can identify societal and work structures that are relevant to my situation.

social-structures.info: Societal structures, such as laws, policy-making, the economy, the education system, culture and the segregation and inequality of the labour market, can affect your career management. For example, some professions are typically dominated by men and others by women, and this can consciously or unconsciously guide your career choices.

ecosocial-factors.name: Eco-social factors

1.title: I can take into account sustainable development and human rights in career management.

ecosocial-factors.info: Being ecosocial in career management means that your strive to take into account the impact on the environment and the wellbeing of other people in your career choices. This can help you find a career that is meaningful and in line with your values.

1.title: Learn to identify opportunities that suit your situation
1.feedback: Did the exercise help you identify opportunities that are appropriate to your situation?  Opportunities refer to alternative paths and possibilities offered by life. A constraint is any limitation that affects your decision-making process or plans. They may include health, place of residence and labour market conditions.

1.title: Write a short description of your current situation or goals.
1.description: For example, are you looking for a new job, wanting to develop a new skill or planning a new project?

2.title: List 1–3 possible ways to proceed in your situation.
2.description: For example, attending courses, applying for jobs, meeting new people.

3.title: Choose one option from your list and answer the following questions:
3.description:
How realistic is this possibility?
What resources or skills do you need to take advantage of it?
What are the next steps in reaching this possibility?
Consider the challenges you might face in implementing the plan.

2.title: Learn to compare the opportunities and constraints related to each option
2.feedback: Hopefully this helped you clarify your thoughts. Opportunities refer to alternative paths and possibilities offered by life. A constraint is any limitation that affects your decision-making process or plans. They may include health, place of residence and labour market conditions.

1.title: Write a short description of your current situation or goals.
1.description: For example, are you looking for a new job, wanting to develop a new skill or planning a new project?

2.title: List 2–5 possible ways to proceed in your situation.
2.description: For example, attending courses, applying for jobs, meeting new people.

3.title: Compare these alternative ways. How do the options differ from each other?

4.title: Which option would suit you best? What challenges might you face in implementing this plan?

3.title: Learn how to develop your career and future plans within the constraints
3.feedback: Did the exercise help you consider the constraints better in terms of your future plan?    Opportunities refer to alternative paths and possibilities offered by life. A constraint is any limitation that affects your decision-making process or plans. They may include health, place of residence and labour market conditions.

1.title: Select a future plan you want to think about in relation to the constraints.

2.title: List the constraints that may affect your plan
2.description: E.g. location, education, skills, budget, schedule, resources, daily demands

3.title: Assess which constraints are most critical, and which ones you can and cannot influence.

1.title: Learn to recognise changes in working life
1.feedback: Great! Understanding the changes in the working life and work will help you direct your career in a goal-oriented manner.
1.description: Working life is always changing. The global economy, new technologies, robotisation, developing digitalisation and the ageing population are key changes in the working life. The ways of working and professions are changing. Look at the below words related to work, working life and working.

1.title: Choose the ones you want as part of your working life:

2.title: Choose the ones you do not want as part of your working life:
Learn how to assess the development and demands of the working life and reflect them to your plans
2.feedback: Good! Developing your capacity for change and having a lifelong learning attitude are good safeguards for your future career.

1.title: Study the information available on the working life. Consider which skills and competencies are needed now and which will be needed in the future.
1.description: Use, for example, <0>sitra.fi</0> and <1>www.osaamistarvekompassi.fi</1> as well as industry reports.

2.title: Reflect the information you find to your situation and plans.
2.description: Think about which changes in the working life will most affect your plans and how you can prepare for them.

world-around-you.info: Knowing the operating environment will help you understand the opportunities and challenges around you. Knowing the requirements and trends in the labour market and in your field will help you keep your competence and objectives up to date in a changing world.

1.description: It is important to be aware of the factors in your environment that affect your career and your life. Remember to remain open to new perspectives and ready to learn more. Responsible consumption and respect for the environment are also important steps towards a sustainable future.

2.description: You have identified your main opportunities and the preconditions that affect them. You can analyse the situation on the labour market and study opportunities. You are aware of how social structures work and their impact on opportunities. Keep up the good work and be open to new learning opportunities!

3.description: You are good at comparing opportunities and constraints as well as in choosing the best options for your situation. Examining the labour market and assessing training needs are important skills. Keep up the good work – you are on the right track!

4.description: Great! You know your operating environment very well! Understanding the structures of and changes in society will help you plan better, and taking into account ecosocial factors is important for a sustainable future. Flexibility and open-mindedness are important qualities in a changing working life.

together-ahead.name: Moving forward together

articulating-competence.name: Articulating competentce

1.title: I can talk about my competence and give practical examples
Your elevator pitch

articulating-competence.info: Articulating your skills means clearly stating what you can do and what you are good at. This is important, for example, when you are looking for a job and want to tell others about your skills.

communication.name: Communication

1.title: I can express myself in different communication situations.

communication.info: Communication refers to the way people talk or express things to each other. Communication can be verbal or non-verbal. Good communication helps you explain your goals and skills clearly. It is important when you want to network or collaborate.

interaction-in-work-study-and-networks.name: Interaction at work, in studies and networks

1.title: I know how to act in various interaction situations.

2.title: I know how networks can help me in my studies, work and life.

interaction-in-work-study-and-networks.info: Interaction refers to people exchanging ideas and opinions and working together. Good interaction is based on listening and working together. Networking refers to creating and maintaining useful relationships with other people.

asking-and-utilizing-help.name: Asking for and using others’ help

1.title: I know how to ask for and get help with choices that are important to me.

asking-and-utilizing-help.info: You are not alone in thinking about your career. You can ask for help from family, friends or various societal services, for example. Asking for help can help you move forward with your career plans.

societal-services.name: Services provided by society

1.title: I can use the services provided by society in my life and career management.

societal-services.info: Society offers a wide range of services to help you plan your career. These include, for example, training and employment services.

job-search-skills.name: Job search skills

1.title: I can take advantage of employment opportunities that suit my situation and highlight my skills in job search situations.

job-search-skills.info: Job search skills include, for example, being familiar with current job search practices as well as being able to communicate your skills clearly and write good job search documents, such as CVs and job applications.

1.title: Learn to identify your competence and put it into words
1.emojiTitle: Choose descriptive emojis for each item
1.description:
Below, each in its own text box, list 3–5 things you think you are good at. They do not have to be professional skills. You can also think about skills acquired through hobbies and everyday life.
For example: “I am good at listening to others and understanding their points of view”, “I learn new skills quickly”, “I can work with different kinds of people”.

Choose one of the skills and use the text box to give a concrete example of when you used that skill.
For example: “I know how to work with different kinds of people: I took part in a study project where the team members came from different backgrounds and had different strengths. I noticed that some of the team members felt that their ideas were not heard. I started a discussion, giving everyone a chance to share their ideas. This improved the atmosphere in the group, and the project was a great success thanks to the contribution of all participants.”
1.feedback: Great, you are aware of your many important skills and competencies! Articulating your skills means expressing clearly what you can do and what you are good at. This is important when you are looking for a job or working in a group and you want to share your skills with others.

2.title: Learn how to outline and describe your skills
2.description:
Below, each in its own text box, write 3–5 skills you are good at. They can be both professional and personal skills.
For example: languages, performance skills, customer service, listening, social skills, leadership, teamwork, ability to work independently, communication, problem solving, technical skills.

Choose one of the skills and write down how you could apply the skill in different situations. Briefly describe how you could use your chosen skill in three different situations.
For example: “Skill: problem-solving skills. 1. At work, I notice that the team is behind schedule because one phase of the project has been delayed. I can use my problem-solving skills to suggest that we redistribute the work and focus on the most urgent exercises. 2. In group work at school, my team cannot find a suitable topic for a presentation. I can suggest that we each propose three ideas and vote on the best topic. 3. At home, I notice that the family members’ schedules clash and chores get left undone. I will organise a list of exercises and suggest that everyone chooses one chore for the week.”
2.feedback: Describing your skills and identifying their potential applications will help you use them in a variety of ways in your career management and in life. Dare to be bold and confident when you share your skills and achievements.
2.emojiTitle: Choose descriptive emojis for each skill

3.title: Learn how to communicate your skills effectively
3.feedback: Did the exercise help you communicate your skills quickly and clearly? Now is the time to make the most of any opportunities that come your way to share your skills with courage and confidence. Every step takes you closer to your goals.
3.description:
Draft your elevator pitch. An elevator pitch is a short introduction about yourself and your skills. It is designed to express clearly and concisely what you can do and why it is important.

● In the text box below, write a few sentences about yourself. Think about what you are currently doing (e.g. studying or working) and what your strengths are.
For example: “My name is Mari, and I study business administration at a university of applied sciences. I specialise in marketing and have good communication skills.”
● Next, think about your strongest skill that you want to highlight. It can be related to work, studies or hobbies.
