For example: “I am particularly good at social media marketing, and I can use it effectively to increase the visibility of businesses.”
● Next, briefly explain how your skills or competence can benefit, for example, your employer, team or customers.
For example: “I have helped several companies increase their customer numbers through social media campaigns. I have experience of what works best for different audiences.”
● Combine everything into a short 30-second speech. Save your elevator pitch in the notes app on your phone, for example, and practise! Your elevator pitch should be clear and smooth.
For example: “I am Mari, a business student specialised in marketing. I am particularly good at social media marketing and have helped businesses improve their visibility and increase their customer numbers. I am looking for opportunities to use these skills in a marketing team.”

1.title: Learn to identify your communication skills
1.description:
Think of two different communication situations in which you were involved.
For example: an email conversation, messages or meeting in a study/work setting or a conversation with a friend or family member.
1.feedback: Good! Communication happens wherever people meet each other. Communication can be verbal or non-verbal, and there are countless ways, forms and channels of communication. Communication helps you express your goals, aspirations and skills clearly

1.title: Below, reflect how the communication situations differed from each other.
1.description: Do you communicate differently in different contexts, channels and settings? What kind of non-verbal communication (gestures, facial expressions, tone of voice) did you notice in these two situations?

2.title: Learn to assess your communication skills
2.feedback: Great! This exercise helped you understand your communication skills and gave you concrete steps to improve them. Good communication skills will help you network and achieve your career goals.
2.description: Think about a communication situation in which you were involved. Answer the questions below.

1.title: How did you prepare for the communication situation?
1.description: E.g. clarified your objectives, planned ahead, listened to the other party first

2.title: How was the communication?
2.description: Were you understandable, fluent and clear?

3.title: Which communication channels did you use?
3.description: E.g. face-to-face, telephone, email, video meeting, social media

4.title: Were there any challenges?
4.description: E.g. misunderstandings, ambiguity, steering the conversation

5.title: Reflect on how successful the communication situation was. Did you manage to bring out your perspectives and take into account the other person’s situation and points of view?

3.title: Learn to develop your communication skills
3.feedback: Great! You now have concrete steps to develop your communication skills! Good communication skills will help you network and achieve your career goals.

1.title: Below, write down one goal you want to achieve by developing your communication skills.
1.description: For example: “I want to be able to present my ideas clearly and confidently in meetings.”

2.title: Which specific communication skills do you need to develop to achieve this goal?
2.description: For example: “I need to learn how to use visual aids, such as slides, and how to speak convincingly in front of a group.”

3.title: How will you practise these skills?
3.description: For example: “I will practise using PowerPoint and ask my colleagues for feedback on the presentation material. I also plan to practise performing at internal meetings with my department to become a better performer.”

4.title: When are you going to put your skills into practice?
4.description: For example: “I will be making a presentation to the management team in one month regarding my department’s action plan.”

1.title: Learn to notice your interaction strengths
1.feedback: Did the exercise help you identify what your strengths are in terms of interaction? It is important to recognise your way of doing things. Interaction is about skills that are learnt throughout life. If you find an interaction challenging, practising can help you strengthen your ability to deal with it. Confidence and ease of interaction come with repetition, practice and experience.

1.title: From the list below, select five strengths that describe you and that come out when you work in a team, a study group or your network.

2.title: Learn how to use and develop your networks
2.feedback: Great job on identifying and assessing your networks! Your network is an important resource as you develop your career. You should never stop developing your networks. Maintaining regular contact with them, for example, via social media, is an excellent way to strengthen relationships.

1.title: List your current networks: write down all the people and groups with whom you regularly interact.
1.description: For example: Family and friends; current and former colleagues; professional associations; social media networks

2.title: Think about how each network can help you in your career management.
2.description:
For example: 
Can this person or group offer career advice or mentoring?
Do they have information about vacancies or hidden jobs?
Can they help you develop new skills or get training?
Do they have contacts that could be useful in your career?

3.title: Review your list and your assessment. Is there an important network that is missing?
3.description:
For example:
Do you have enough contacts in your industry?
Do you have a mentor or coach?
Are you a member of professional organisations or groups?

4.title: Think about how you can acquire new networks and expand existing ones.
4.description:
For example:
Participate in professional events and seminars.
Be active on social media.
Join professional organisations and groups.
Keep in touch with former colleagues and fellow students.

1.title: Learn to identify where you can find help for your career reflections
1.feedback: Great! Keep in mind: you are not alone in your career reflections. Asking for help from people close to you or using services provided by society can help you move forward as you reflect on your career. Keep up the good work and take advantage of any assistance that can help you move forward.

1.title: Below, list people, places and services that can help and support you with your career reflections.
1.description:
Use these questions to help you make your list:
●  Think about who you can contact in your network. This can include family members, friends and work community.
●  Does your workplace or educational institution have a career counsellor/coach or guidance counsellor?
●  Are you familiar with the employment services that are available in your area? For example, career guidance and counselling.
●  Do you know what opportunities there are for further training or retraining?
●  Do you know any useful service websites? Are you familiar with Job Market Finland and Studyinfo? What kind of help could you get through them?
●  Are you familiar with Ohjaamo?
●  Do you know what kind of support and guidance trade unions or professional organisations can offer?
●  Are there any job search events or networking events in your area where you can get advice and expand your network?

2.title: Learn to find the right kind of help for you
2.feedback: Great! Keep in mind: you are not alone in your career reflections. Asking for help from people close to you or using services provided by society can help you move forward as you reflect on your career. Keep up the good work and take advantage of any assistance that can help you move forward.

1.description:
Use these questions to help you make your list:
●  Think about who you can contact in your network. This can include family members, friends and work community.
●  Does your workplace or educational institution have a career counsellor/coach or guidance counsellor?
●  Are you familiar with the employment services that are available in your area? For example, career guidance and counselling.
●  Do you know what opportunities there are for further training or retraining?
●  Do you know any useful service websites? Are you familiar with Job Market Finland and Studyinfo? What kind of help could you get through them?
●  Are you familiar with Ohjaamo?
●  Do you know what kind of support and guidance trade unions or professional organisations can offer?
●  Are there any job search events or networking events in your area where you can get advice and expand your network?
1.title: Below, list people, places and services that can help and support you in your career reflections.

2.title: Analyse your list and think about the most important places for you to get help and support from as you reflect on your career right now. Which ones could be useful in the long term?

1.title: Learn to identify the services offered by society that can support your life and career management
1.description:
Find out what kind of services society offers for various life situations. Use official websites, such as <0>www.suomi.fi/citizen, to find information about the available services.
For example:
Employment services
Training and retraining programmes
Health and welfare services
Social services and financial assistance
Entrepreneurship support services

1.title: Below, list services provided by society that can help you with life and career management.

1.feedback: Great! Keep in mind: you are not alone in your career reflections. Making use of the services offered by society can help you as you make career-related choices. Take advantage of all the opportunities that can take you forward!

2.title: Learn how to find the right services for you
2.feedback: Great! Keep in mind: you are not alone in your career reflections. Making use of the services offered by society can help you as you make career-related choices. Take advantage of all the opportunities that can take you forward!

1.title: Start by taking stock of your situation: Below, describe your current life and career situation. Think about what your biggest challenges and needs are at the moment.

2.title: Survey the services: Find out what kind of services society offers for various life situations. Use official websites, such as www.suomi.fi/citizen, to find information about the available services.
2.description:
For example:
Employment services
Training and retraining programmes
Health and welfare services
Social services and financial assistance
Entrepreneurship support services

3.title: Assess the services: Make a list of services that could be useful in your situation. Assess how well each service meets your needs and challenges.

4.title: Draw up a plan on how you will use these services.

1.title: Learn to find different kinds of employment opportunities
1.description: Identify the most suitable job opportunities for you. Answer the questions below.
1.feedback: Great! An active attitude will help you find the best jobs for you! Remember that in addition to online job search, personal contacts are an opportunity to find a job.

1.title: Think about the kind of job you are looking for: type (full-time, part-time, freelance), sector (e.g. IT, healthcare, education) and location (local, remote, international).

2.title: Think about your strengths, skills and interests.

3.title: Make a list of the job search channels you could use to find suitable job opportunities for you.
3.description:
For example:
Job Market Finland and other job search sites
Social media
Company websites
Networks

4.title: Explore the channels you listed and write down where you found the most interesting job opportunities.

2.title: Learn how to expand your employment opportunities
2.feedback: Great! When considering career opportunities, it is a good idea to think broadly about where you could use your skills. It is worth looking at your skills from new perspectives. Be open-minded about how you can use your current skills in new working environments.

1.title: Below, identify and write down 3–5 of your skills that could be applied at a wide range of jobs.
1.description: For example, project management, accuracy, communication skills, language skills, customer service.

2.title: Think about the kinds of new jobs or industries these skills could take you to. Think about how you could apply your skills in different industries or jobs.
2.description: For example, if you have communication skills from marketing, can you transfer them to sales, training or consultancy?

3.title: Analyse at least two sectors in which you have not yet applied for a job. You can use job search sites, trade union websites or talk to professionals in these fields. Below, list the new job opportunities you found.

4.title: Choose one of the job opportunities you found and think about how you would describe your skills in relation to that job.

together-ahead.info: Good interaction and cooperation skills will help you find new opportunities, discover new things and get help to further your situation. Interpersonal and cooperation skills are also reflected in how you show your appreciation to others and how you share your skills, goals and aspirations.

1.description: Operating in a variety of interaction situations provides a good basis for career management. Being aware of the different ways to find job opportunities will help you prepare for the future. Keep up the good work and remember to use the skills you have learnt in future situations.

2.description: You are already good at structuring and describing your competence in various ways. For example, articulating your skills will help you understand your strengths and areas of development. Remember to take into account the different ways of communicating and interacting – they will affect how you are understood. It is great that you can identify people and networks that can help you.

3.description: Excellent! You are aware of your many important skills and competence areas. You are ready to apply your skills in different situations. Remember to be open to feedback and use it in your learning. Networks are very important for career development. Continue to build and maintain networks. Remember that every situation and challenge is an opportunity to learn and grow. Retain your positive attitude and keep developing your skills!

4.description: Great! You can communicate in a goal-oriented manner and effectively to different target groups as well as create and maintain professional networks. You are also able to make use of different services and anticipate your career needs in the long term. This is valuable when you want to highlight your skills!

anticipate-the-future.name: Anticipating the future
anticipate-the-future.long-name: Understanding the future of the operating environment

alternative-paths.name: Alternative paths

1.title: I know how to look for alternative paths that suit my situation.

alternative-paths.info: Exploring alternative paths and decision-making will continue throughout life as work and personal circumstances change. Opportunities and chances may come your way that help you achieve your goals. You can contribute to building new, alternative paths through your actions.

1.title: I keep track of societal changes that may affect my situation and can take them into account in my career management.

social-changes.name: Changes in society
social-changes.info: Changes in society, such as digitalisation, artificial intelligence, the means used to combat climate change and the ageing population, can affect career management.

global-changes.name: Global changes

1.title: I keep track of global changes that may affect my situation and can take them into account in my career management.

global-changes.info: Global changes, such as climate change, economic cycles and regional conflicts, can affect your career management.

1.name: Learn how to identify alternative career paths
1.feedback: Excellent work! You have shown an ability to explore alternative paths. This skill is particularly valuable as the working life and your personal circumstances change. Keep up the good work and continue building new alternative pathways!
1.description: Various paths can lead to the same goal. The path does not necessarily have to follow a traditional career path. Along the way, you can come by opportunities and coincidences that are worth seizing.

1.title: Write down one of your future goals.

2.title: Below, think about the various alternative paths you can follow to achieve your future goal.
2.description: Also consider the concrete steps and steps you need to take to achieve this goal. Describe these steps below.

2.name: Learn how to map alternative career paths
2.description: Alternative career paths provide different routes to professional development and progression, which do not necessarily follow a traditional, straightforward career path. Coincidence and unexpected situations can also shape the journey by opening up new opportunities and changes of direction that will further enrich your career development.
2.feedback: Great job! It is great to see that you are ready to seize chance opportunities and possibilities to help you achieve your goals. This skill is particularly valuable as your work and personal circumstances change. Keep up the good work and continue building new alternative pathways! This attitude and approach will take you far!

1.title: Think about how your decisions and chance events have impacted your life so far.
1.description: Write down your main thought below.

2.title: Make a mind map of the various alternative paths you could consider in the future.
2.description: Include paths related to both your career and personal life. Below, list the most feasible alternative paths.

3.name: Learn how to build alternative career paths towards your future
3.description: Alternative career paths provide different routes to professional development and progression, which do not necessarily follow a traditional, straightforward career path. Coincidence and unexpected situations can also shape the journey by opening up new opportunities and changes of direction that will further enrich your career development.
3.feedback: Great job! It is great to see that you are ready to seize chance opportunities and possibilities to help you achieve your goals. This skill is particularly valuable as your work and personal circumstances change. Keep up the good work and continue building new alternative pathways! This attitude and approach will take you far!

1.title: Think about how your decisions and chance events have impacted your life so far.
1.description: Write down your main thought below.

2.title: Make a mind map of the various alternative paths you could consider in the future.
2.description: Include paths related to both your career and personal life. Below, list the most feasible alternative paths.

3.title: Below, think about how you can contribute to building new alternative pathways through your actions.
3.description: Think about the skills and resources you need and how you can gain them.

1.title: Learn how to identify changes in society that can affect your career opportunities
1.description: Society is constantly changing, making the need to learn new things more and more important throughout your life.

1.title: Consider whether the changes listed below are visible in your life:
1.description:
Technological development (e.g. growth of artificial intelligence, automation) 
Activities related to climate change (e.g. green transition, sustainable development) 
Changes in the labour market (e.g. remote work, number of freelancers)
Changes in occupations and jobs

1.feedback: Amazing job! You can already recognise changes in society that can affect your life and career plans. This skill is very important because it will help you prepare for future challenges and opportunities.

2.title: Learn how to acknowledge societal changes in your career management
2.description: Society is constantly changing, making the need to learn new things more and more important throughout your life.
2.feedback: Amazing job! Many societal changes can impact career management, such as digitalisation, the rise of artificial intelligence, the means used to combat climate change and the ageing population.

1.title: Choose one societal change and think about how it could affect your life and career management:
1.description:
For example:
Technological development (e.g. growth of artificial intelligence, automation) 
Activities related to climate change (e.g. green transition, sustainable development) 
Changes in the labour market (e.g. remote work, number of freelancers) 
Changes in occupations and jobs 
Ageing population

3.title: Learn how to use forecasts and take account of societal changes in your career management
3.description:
Identify the main trends currently underway in Finland that will affect future career opportunities. What key changes are expected? What kind of opportunities and challenges will they bring?

Make use of national forecasts, such as the Government’s Reports on the Future, Sitra’s website, the osaamistarvekompassi.fi website, Labour Force Barometer (tyovoimabarometri.fi) or reports from the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment.
3.feedback: Amazing job! Many societal changes can impact career management, such as digitalisation, the rise of artificial intelligence, the means used to combat climate change and the ageing population.

1.title: Think about how these trends and possible changes relate to your career. Write down your thoughts on how you can anticipate new skill requirements or jobs that may be important in the future.
Learn to identify global changes in society that can affect your career opportunities
1.description: There are various global changes, such as climate change, economic upturns and downturns, digitalisation as well as regional conflicts.
1.feedback: Amazing job! You can already recognise global changes that could affect your life and career management. This is a very useful skill as it can help you prepare for future challenges and opportunities.

1.title: Reflect on how global changes affect your life.

2.title: Learn how to take global changes into account in your career management
2.description: There are various global changes, such as climate change, economic upturns and downturns, digitalisation as well as regional conflicts.
2.feedback: Great! Global changes, such as climate change, economic cycles and regional conflicts, can affect your career management. Understanding future trends and major changes will help you prepare for any changes in your working life. By anticipating which skills and competencies will be needed in the future, you can build purposeful pathways to a future of your choosing.

1.title: Take a closer look at one global change and consider how it could affect your life and career management.

3.title: Learn how to use forecasts and take global changes into account in your career management
3.description:
Examine future trends and forecasts: Identify the key global trends currently affecting future career opportunities. What key changes are expected? What kind of opportunities and challenges will they bring?

Make use of national forecasts, such as the Government’s Reports on the Future, Sitra’s website, the osaamistarvekompassi.fi website or reports from the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment.
3.feedback: Great! Global changes, such as climate change, economic cycles and regional conflicts, can affect your career management. Understanding future trends and major changes will help you prepare for any changes in your working life. By anticipating which skills and competencies will be needed in the future, you can build purposeful pathways to a future of your choosing.

1.title: Think about how these global trends and possible changes relate to your career. Write down your thoughts on how you can anticipate new skill requirements or jobs that may be important in the future.

anticipate-the-future.info: Understanding future trends and major changes will help you prepare for changes in the working life. This skill will help you anticipate the skills and competences you will need in the future and build purposeful paths to your future.

1.description: Based on your self-assessment, you are ready to develop your ability to understand the future of your environment – perfect! This is an important skill that will help you better understand and adapt to changes around you. Remember that curiosity and openness are key to learning new things.

2.description: You are able to identify the key paths that will help you achieve your goals. You also understand that your actions have an impact on building new alternative paths. It is also important to be aware of changes in society. You are clearly aware of the fact that these changes can affect the way you plan your life and career. Keep up the good work!

3.description: Excellent work in being able to identify the potential changes in your job and role in the future. It is important to compare different paths and have the ability to choose the options that suit you best. You can assess what the changes mean for your career path. Continue to actively seek knowledge and monitor global changes. You are on the right track to a successful career!

4.description: You are able to assess and prepare for future changes in your work and industries you are interested in. This is an important skill that will help you succeed in your career. Remember to continue to actively seek information and follow global developments. This will help you stay up to date and understand the new competence needs that the changes will bring. You are on the right track to a successful career!

1.title: Learn to look for new learning opportunities
1.feedback: Great! At different stages of your life and career, you can learn, train and study in different ways. In a changing world, you need to develop your skills constantly.
1.description: Lifelong learning means that people continue to learn new things throughout their lives, whether in the form of formal education, work or free-time activities.

1.title: Below, write down a skill or competence you would like to develop.
1.description:
It does not have to be directly related to working or studying – it can also be a personal or hobby-related skill.
For example: time management skills, learning a new technology, communication skills, promoting wellbeing.

2.title: Write about some flexible ways in which you can develop your skill or competence.
2.description:
Think about how you could acquire competence. Use these questions to help you:
- Can you learn in short periods of time, such as 10–20 minutes, with e.g. YouTube videos, podcasts or mobile apps?
- Can you participate in online courses that are self-paced and flexible according to your schedule? 
- Can you learn new skills at work (e.g. apprenticeship)?
- Could you take courses organised by educational institutions or participate in training leading to a qualification? 
- Do you know someone who could teach you this?

2.title: Learn how to find study opportunities that suit your situation
2.feedback: Great! At different stages of your life and career, you can learn, train and study in different ways. In a changing world, you need to develop your skills constantly.

1.title: Find two study opportunities that suit you and compare them to each other. Take advantage of the Opintopolku.fi website, where you can find both degree programmes as well as further education and training opportunities.
1.description:
For example, consider the following:
- What kind of skills do you need more of and what are your goals?
- How well do the options meet your objectives, e.g. short courses, training programmes/degrees, online courses?
- What types of study options do they offer? E.g. day studies, hybrid learning, e-learning, apprenticeships.
- What is the content of the training?

1.title: Learn to identify the social and work structures that affect you
1.description:
Think about how the structures of society affect you. Choose one of the three imaginary situations below to reflect on or think about your own situation. Write your answer below.
Examples of societal structures: legislation, political decision-making, economy, education system, culture, labour market, gender roles.

1. I want to learn a new profession for myself.
For example: “The economic situation affects the labour market and the funding of education”, “Student financial aid helps”, “The needs of the labour market are changing”.

2. I am exhausted at work and need a break from the working life.
For example: “Flexibility in the workplace supports coping”, “General attitudes to burnout and recovery have an impact”.

3. I have a good business idea and want to start a business.
For example: “Business legislation and start-up funds support the founding of a company”, “The financial and competitive environment affect business operations”.
1.feedback: Societal structures influence life and career management. This is important to be aware of, as it will help you make more informed decisions in the future. Keep up the good work and continue deepening your understanding.

1.title: Thoughts on chosen situation

2.title: Learn how to detect structural changes as you plan your career
2.feedback: Societal structures and the changes they undergo affect life and career management. This is important to be aware of, as it will help you make more informed decisions and plans.

1.title: Choose one societal structure that could influence your career plans.
1.description: For example: Technological developments (automation, digitalisation); Changes in the labour market (remote work, freelancing); Education policy and accessibility; Legislation (labour law, working time regulation); Economic situation (inflation, salary trends)

2.title: Consider how the societal structure you chose currently affects your career opportunities.
2.description:
Include concrete examples.
For example: “With digitalisation, many jobs have become remote positions, which allows me to apply for jobs in different countries.”

3.title: Also consider how this structure might change over the next 5–10 years and what kind of an impact it might have on your career.
3.description: For example: “If automation and AI continue to develop, some manual exercises may disappear, while technological skills will become more important. This may mean that I need to acquire more technical skills.”

3.title: Learn to anticipate the impact of changes in societal structures as you plan your career
3.feedback: Societal structures and the changes they undergo affect life and career management. Anticipating change is important because it helps you make more informed decisions and future plans.

1.title: Choose one societal structure that could influence your career plans.
1.description: For example: Technological developments (automation, digitalisation); Changes in the labour market (remote work, freelancing); Education policy and accessibility; Legislation (labour laws, working time regulation); Economic situation (inflation, wage trends)

2.title: Consider how the societal structure you have chosen currently affects your career opportunities.
2.description:
Include concrete examples.
For example: “With digitalisation, many jobs have become remote positions, which allows me to apply for jobs in different countries.”

3.title: Also consider how this structure might change over the next 5–10 years and what kind of an impact it might have on your career.
3.description: Example: “If automation and AI continue to develop, some manual exercises may disappear, while technological skills will become more important. This may mean that I need to acquire more technical skills.”

4.title: Think about what you can do now to be ready for any upcoming changes.
4.description: For example: “I could participate in further training or courses to improve my technology skills to be competitive in the labour market in the future.”

1.title: Learn how to promote eco-social wellbeing in the working life
1.description: Take a moment to reflect on your thoughts on sustainability and the green transition, which are already affecting many professions.
1.feedback: Good! Eco-social factors in career management refer to promoting sustainable development and human rights in career management, which can be seen in, for example, the choice of job or education. Considering eco-social factors during the career management process can help individuals find a meaningful and value-based career that supports both personal wellbeing and social sustainability.

1.title: Choose one occupation or job and think about how it contributes to the wellbeing of people or nature.
1.description: For example: doctor, machinist, teacher, engineer, social worker, master builder, forest machine business owner, business college graduate, sustainable development specialist.

2.title: Write a short description of the job and its impact:
2.description: How does this job improve people’s quality of life? How does it contribute to the wellbeing of nature?

2.title: Learn how to consider eco-social factors in your life
2.description: Below, consider how eco-social factors influence your life and choices.
2.feedback: Great! Eco-social factors in career management refer to promoting sustainable development and human rights in career management, which can be seen in, for example, the choice of job or education. Considering eco-social factors during the career management process can help individuals find a meaningful and value-based career that supports both personal wellbeing and social sustainability.

service-info.title: Career Skills Tool - About the service
service-info.description:
Career Skills is a digital tool to help you assess and develop your career management skills. By answering self-assessment questions, you can find out which career management skills you are strong in and which skills you should develop.
After the self-assessment, you will receive suggestions for exercises to help you develop your career management skills.

The tool is free of charge and can be used without logging in. Your answers will be saved until you close the browser window. You can save the self-assessment summary as a link or in PDF format. You can save the exercises you have done in PDF format.

Hyria implemented the Career Skills tool as part of the Career Management Skills Promotion project managed by the Ministry of Employment and the Economy and the KEHA Centre. Funding for the project comes from the EU's Recovery and Regeneration Instrument.

For more information on Hyria's development work and support material for instructors, please visit: <0>www.hyria.fi/urasuunnittelutaidot

The Career Skills tool will be integrated into the CompetencyPath service by the end of 2025.

career-plan.title: Career Plan

1.title: What strengths, skills, and knowledge do you have?

2.title: What are your most important values? Are you living according to your values?

3.title: What are you currently satisfied with? And what would you like to change?

4.title: What are your goals for the next year? And for the next 5–10 years?

5.title: What changes or new developments are happening in your field or the field you aim to pursue? What should you at least consider for the future?

6.title: What additional skills do you need to achieve your goals?

7.title: What are the potential obstacles, and how can you overcome them?

8.title: Where could you get help to achieve your plans? Who can you talk to about your dreams and aspirations?

9.title: What concrete steps will you take next? What about in the next year?

10.title: How will you track the progress of your plan?

career-plan.question-description: If you need help answering this question, complete the following exercises:
career-plan.feedback: Be ready to adjust your targets if necessary. If you find that a goal is too challenging, change it to a more realistic one. Allow for chance! Remember to reward yourself along the way when you achieve your sub-goals. This can be a small reward that motivates you to keep going.
